author: By Megan Specia
title: Philip’s funeral nods to a life of service and his ‘unwavering loyalty’ to the queen.
description: Queen Elizabeth II, wearing a black mask and seated alone, said goodbye to her husband of more than 73 years, Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, at his funeral on Saturday at St. George’s Chapel in Windsor Castle.
content: Queen Elizabeth II, wearing a black mask and seated alone, said goodbye to her husband of more than 73 years, Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, at his funeral on Saturday at St. George’s Chapel in Windsor Castle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Louis Lucero II
title: Seeing the queen alone adds a painful note for many watching from home.
description: She was utterly alone.
content: She was utterly alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Can Covid Research Help Solve the Mysteries of Other Viruses?
description: The coronavirus may help scientists understand why some people with common viral infections develop severe complications, like heart damage or blood clots.
content: Barie Carmichael lost her sense of taste and smell while traveling in Europe. She remembers keeping a dinner date at a Michelin-starred restaurant but tasting nothing. “I didn’t have the heart to tell my host,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Brantley
title: How Helen McCrory Shone, Even in a Haze of Mystery
description: She was unforgettable onstage playing seemingly serene women who rippled with restlessness.
content: Selfishly, my first feelings on hearing that the uncanny British actress Helen McCrory had died at 52 were of personal betrayal. We were supposed to have shared a long and fruitful future together, she and I. There’d be me on one side of the footlights and her on the other, as she unpacked the secrets of the human heart with a grace and ruthlessness shared by only a few theater performers in each generation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gregory Cowles
title: When Harry Met Harry
description: In Dan Gutman’s “Houdini and Me,” a boy named Harry who lives in Houdini’s old house is getting text messages from the long-dead magician’s ghost.
content: HOUDINI AND MEBy Dan Gutman
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Biden Choice for Justice Dept.’s No. 2 Is Seen as a Consensus Builder
description: Lisa Monaco, a veteran of national security posts, is expected to be a key player in the administration’s push to combat domestic extremism, embodied most publicly in the department’s inquiry into the Capitol attack.
content: WASHINGTON — Lisa Monaco was President Barack Obama’s top counterterrorism adviser when she was handed an intractable problem: Fix the administration’s ineffective response to the kidnappings of Americans by Islamic State fighters, which had prompted outcries from victims’ families, without changing the government’s refusal to make concessions to terrorists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Biden Ditches the Generals, Finally
description: Another casualty in the graveyard of empires.
content: WASHINGTON — Afghanistan has a complicated relationship with time. And America has a complicated relationship with revenge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Highest French Court Rules Killer of Jewish Woman Cannot Stand Trial
description: To the alarm of Jewish leaders, Sarah Halimi’s killer will go unpunished because of his mental state, brought on by cannabis, at the time of the crime.
content: PARIS — The highest court in France has ruled that the man who killed a Jewish woman in 2017 in an anti-Semitic frenzy cannot stand trial because he was in a state of acute mental delirium brought on by his consumption of cannabis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Biden Administration Ends Limits on Use of Fetal Tissue for Research
description: The decision reverses Trump administration rules and allows scientists to use tissue derived from elective abortions to develop treatments for diseases including cancer and AIDS.
content: The Biden administration on Friday lifted restrictions on the use of fetal tissue for medical research, reversing rules imposed in 2019 by President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: The shooting in Indianapolis adds to a grim toll of workplace violence in the U.S.
description: Mass shootings in American workplaces are not a new phenomenon.
content: The man who opened fire at a FedEx facility in Indianapolis late Thursday, fatally shooting eight people and injuring at least seven others, was a former employee at the facility, a spokesman for FedEx said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Moyo and Christina Goldbaum
title: In a bid to curb the virus, Zimbabwe releases hundreds of prisoners.
description: At least 320 prisoners were released on Saturday in an effort to ease congestion in the country’s notoriously crowded jails.
content: HARARE, Zimbabwe — Zimbabwe released at least 320 prisoners from its jails on Saturday to ease congestion in the country’s notoriously overcrowded jails as a second wave of the coronavirus devastates the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas and Noah Weiland
title: The Covid-19 Plasma Boom Is Over. What Did We Learn From It?
description: The U.S. government invested $800 million in plasma when the country was desperate for Covid-19 treatments. A year later, the program has fizzled.
content: Scott Cohen was on a ventilator struggling for his life with Covid-19 last April when his brothers pleaded with Plainview Hospital on Long Island to infuse him with the blood plasma of a recovered patient.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Post-Merkel Germany May Be Shaded Green
description: Germany’s Greens are expected to be a critical part of any new government. But these are not the Greens of old. Today it is a pragmatic party promising an assertive stance abroad.
content: Whatever government fills the vacuum in Germany after Chancellor Angela Merkel will be tinged with green.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Prince Philip Is Laid to Rest in a Somber 50-Minute Ceremony
description: The televised and live-streamed rite afforded Britons a chance to witness a seeming slight easing in the strained relations between Princes William and Harry.
content: LONDON — His coffin borne on a military green Land Rover that he had helped design, Prince Philip was laid to rest on Saturday at Windsor Castle in an austere, meticulously choreographed funeral that captured his steely role in Britain’s royal family and offered a solemn glimpse of its uncertain future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: With attendance limited to 30, a look at who was at the funeral.
description: Amid coronavirus restrictions, Britain has had to adjust how it grieves over the past year. And with current rules allowing for just 30 people at funerals, the royal family scaled back plans for the service for Prince Philip.
content: Amid coronavirus restrictions, Britain has had to adjust how it grieves over the past year. And with current rules allowing for just 30 people at funerals, the royal family scaled back plans for the service for Prince Philip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Make Tax-Dodging Companies Pay for Biden’s Infrastructure Plan
description: The corporate income tax has been gutted. Raising rates and cracking down on evasion are sensible ways to come up with trillions of dollars.
content: American companies and companies that make money in the United States are not paying enough money in taxes. Even as profits have soared, tax payments have declined. Fifty-five of the nation’s largest corporations — including FedEx, Nike and the agribusiness giant Archer Daniels Midland — paid nothing in federal income taxes in 2020, despite collectively reporting more than $40 billion in profits, according to the Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A-J Aronstein
title: I Have Read Thousands of Résumés, and I Have Some Advice
description: The history of this strange document can tell job seekers what works and what doesn’t.
content: In the last decade, I have revised 3,000 résumés while working as a college career adviser. Here is my advice: The strongest will fit on a single page. Exceptions are few. An 8.5 by 11 inch sheet of letter paper fits about 700 words. So be efficient. Recruiters often say they spend six seconds reviewing the average candidate. Are you worth seven?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon and Shawn Hubler
title: Throughout Trial Over George Floyd’s Death, Killings by Police Mount
description: Since testimony in Derek Chauvin’s trial began on March 29, more than three people a day have died at the hands of law enforcement.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — Just seven hours before prosecutors opened their case against Derek Chauvin, a former Minneapolis police officer charged with murdering George Floyd, a Chicago officer chased down a 13-year-old boy in a West Side alley and fatally shot him as he turned with his hands up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Aleksei Navalny Needs His Doctors
description: Vladimir Putin may be able to save his nemesis’ life. He must.
content: Aleksei Navalny’s wife, doctor and colleagues have sounded an anguished alarm that the incarcerated Kremlin critic’s health is rapidly deteriorating and his heart could stop any minute. They and many other supporters of Mr. Navalny are demanding that his doctors be immediately allowed to see and treat him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: 100 Days Without Trump on Twitter: A Nation Scrolls More Calmly
description: Democrats are breathing easier. Republicans are crying censorship. For all of the country’s news consumers, a strange quiet has descended after a four-year bombardment of presidential verbiage.
content: That soothing sound that Gary Cavalli hears emanating from Twitter these days? It is the sound of silence — specifically, the silence of former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: How to Help a Grieving Neighbor
description: Grief can be a lonely process, made lonelier by a pandemic that has kept us apart from the people we love.
content: Q: I live in a close-knit Upper East Side rental building, where neighbors trade phone numbers and collect one another’s packages. The woman who lives below me lost her husband in August after an illness. Since then, I’ve heard her wailing, talking and cursing to herself, clearly in despair. The neighbor below her also can hear the noises, but we don’t know how to approach this. I have offered the widow help with errands when I see her, so she knows we’re here for her, but she declines, and I don’t think that would really help anyway. Any advice on how we can handle this?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy Tarng
title: When Her Mother Died, She Found Solace at a Korean Grocery
description: Michelle Zauner, a musician who performs under the name Japanese Breakfast, is making her book debut with “Crying in H Mart.”
content: After an hour of discussing her mother, the afterlife and the shamelessness sometimes required in producing art, Michelle Zauner adjusted her video camera to show her Bushwick apartment. Her coffee table, suddenly in view, was covered with Jolly Pong Cereal Snack, NongShim Shrimp Crackers, Lotte Malang Cow Milk Candies and other Asian junk food.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: After Bullying Reports, Scott Rudin Says He’ll Step Back From Broadway
description: The powerful producer of “Hello, Dolly!” and “The Book of Mormon” regrets “the pain my behavior caused” and says others will directly run his shows.
content: Scott Rudin, a powerful Broadway producer facing renewed accusations of bullying, apologized Saturday for “troubling interactions with colleagues” and said he would step aside from “active participation” in his current shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr, Mitch Smith and Campbell Robertson
title: In a Spasm of Violence, Indianapolis Faces the Country’s Latest Mass Shooting
description: The country grappled with yet another bloody rampage, only weeks after back-to-back mass shootings last month in Atlanta and Boulder, Colo.
content: INDIANAPOLIS — He appeared in the parking lot after dark — a hooded figure with a gun who immediately began spraying bullets in every direction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Special Cryptic
description: John Halpern and a cast of characters turn in our first crowdsourced cryptic crossword — and it’s for a good cause!
content: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD — Today we have a puzzle from a prolific “setter,” or constructor, making his New York Times debut, although he’s quite a capo di cryptic in England. If you have ever solved a puzzle by “Mudd” in the Financial Times, “Dada” in The Telegraph, “Mara” in The Times (U.K. — requires a subscription) or “Punk” in The Independent, then you’ve already tried your hand at a John Halpern creation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Ivory, Lauren Leatherby and Robert Gebeloff
title: In counties that voted for Trump, fewer people are getting vaccinated.
description: The New York Times examined survey and vaccine administration data for nearly every U.S. county and found that both willingness to receive a vaccine and actual vaccination rates to date were lower, on average, in counties where a majority of residents voted to re-elect former President Donald J. Trump in 2020.
content: The New York Times examined survey and vaccine administration data for nearly every U.S. county and found that both willingness to receive a vaccine and actual vaccination rates to date were lower, on average, in counties where a majority of residents voted to re-elect former President Donald J. Trump in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Swiss Billionaire Is Said to End His Bid for Tribune Publishing
description: Hansjörg Wyss was part of a serious offer for the major newspaper chain that could have prevented it from being sold to the hedge fund Alden Global Capital.
content: The Swiss billionaire Hansjörg Wyss, who seemingly came out of nowhere last month to make a serious offer for Tribune Publishing, a major newspaper chain, has decided to take himself out of the bidding, according to three people with knowledge of the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Democrats Aim to Revive a Campaign Finance Watchdog
description: Republicans denounced the proposed overhaul as an attempt to mount a partisan takeover of what critics consider a moribund Federal Election Commission.
content: WASHINGTON — Even in a dysfunctional capital, the Federal Election Commission has long stood out for monumental dysfunction.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: The Contradiction That Doomed America’s Mission in Afghanistan
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, April 17, 2021.
content: “You can’t actually parachute in a consolidated state. But that’s what we were trying to do.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Conor Dougherty
title: One Way to Get People Off the Streets: Buy Hotels
description: For homeless people, a place to live is life changing to a degree that almost no other intervention can provide.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — The inside of the van was lined with plastic. The driver was masked and ready to go. There was a seat for just one passenger.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Shine a Spotlight on Peas
description: It’s a great time for peas, whether you pair them with pasta or with rice.
content: Asparagus and rhubarb steal much of the spotlight this time of year, leaving the modest pea waiting in the wings. Now is its time to shine — in Melissa Clark’s pasta primavera, our most popular recipe of the week, or in this recipe for risi e bisi, the latest from Gabrielle Hamilton. Even its cousin, the sugar snap pea, deserves some time in the sun with Melissa Clark’s spiced salmon with sugar snap peas and red onion (above). You’ll find plenty more dishes packed with spring flavors in our collection of the most popular New York Times Cooking recipes of the week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: Rusty Young, Country-Rock Pioneer, Is Dead at 75
description: As a founding member of the band Poco, he helped define a genre and establish the pedal steel guitar as an integral voice in West Coast rock.
content: Rusty Young, a founding member of the popular country-rock group Poco and a key figure in establishing the pedal steel guitar as an integral voice in the West Coast rock of the late 1960s and ’70s, died on Wednesday at his home in Davisville, Mo. He was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: The Republican Retreat on World Affairs
description: What will G.O.P. foreign policy be post-Trump? Who knows!
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your wrap-up of the week in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Libresco Sargeant
title: Why Anti-Abortion Catholics Should Get Vaccinated
description: Qualms about the vaccines’ development are not entirely misguided. But we can make amends for past injustice.
content: America is rapidly approaching the point where demand, not supply, is the limiting factor of our vaccine rollout. Our job now is hearing out the worries of vaccine-hesitant friends and trying to assuage their concerns. My fellow Catholics are one group in need of assurance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: Danica Roem, a Pathbreaking Lawmaker, on the Fight for Trans Rights
description: Ms. Roem, a Virginia delegate who in 2018 became the first openly transgender legislator in the country, spoke with The Times about Republicans’ anti-trans crusade and how Democrats can push back.
content: While Republican-controlled legislatures across the country are passing a flurry of bills aimed at limiting transgender rights and medical care, Virginia is going the opposite way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Peloton Fights Back Against U.S. Warnings of Treadmill Dangers
description: The U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission said it was aware of 38 injuries and one death related to Peloton’s Tread+ machine. The company said its product is safe.
content: The exercise bike company Peloton fought back on Saturday after a federal agency warned that those with children at home should stop using the company’s Tread+ treadmills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and David E. Sanger
title: Debating Exit From Afghanistan, Biden Rejected Generals’ Views
description: Over two decades of war, the Pentagon had fended off the political instincts of elected leaders frustrated with the grind of Afghanistan. But President Biden refused to be persuaded.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden used his daily national security briefing on the morning of April 6 to deliver the news that his senior military leaders suspected was coming. He wanted all American troops out of Afghanistan by Sept. 11, the 20th anniversary of the attacks on New York and the Pentagon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives, Sameer Yasir and Muktita Suhartono
title: As Covid Death Toll Passes 3 Million, a Weary World Takes Stock
description: “It just never crossed your mind that there would be so many dead in so little time,” said one man in Mexico City.
content: Three million lives: That is roughly equivalent to losing the population of Berlin, Chicago or Taipei. The scale is so staggering that it sometimes begins to feel real only in places like graveyards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Rays Continue Their Domination of Struggling Yankees
description: Tampa Bay’s latest victory dropped the Yankees to 5-8. Meanwhile the Mets had yet another game postponed.
content: Brandon Lowe hit a two-run double in the first inning off opener Nick Nelson, and the Tampa Bay Rays kept up their domination of the Yankees with an 8-2 win Friday night that set off frustrated fans who caused a brief interruption.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel L. Swarns
title: A Catholic Order Pledged $100 Million to Atone for Taking Part in the Slave Trade. Some Descendants Want a New Deal.
description: The deal had been hammered out in a series of private meetings between the Jesuits and three descendant leaders.
content: Ronda Thompson got the astounding news in a text from her sister. The Jesuits, the prominent order of Catholic priests that had enslaved her ancestors, had vowed to raise $100 million to atone for participating in the American slave trade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins, Campbell Robertson and Andrés R. Martínez
title: Indianapolis police chief says gunman bought weapons legally despite earlier warning.
description: Chief Randal Taylor said the gunman in the attack bought two assault-style weapons in July and September. Months earlier, his mother had warned the police about his mental state.
content: Brandon Hole, the 19-year-old who the police say fatally shot eight people at a FedEx facility on Thursday night, legally purchased two semiautomatic rifles he used in the attack more than six months earlier, according to the chief of the Indianapolis Metropolitan Police Department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Brallier
title: Pseudonymous Bosch’s First Book Under His Real Name
description: In “The Anti-Book,” Raphael Simon explores what happens when a bubble gum prize enables an angry boy to erase everything he hates about his life.
content: THE ANTI-BOOKBy Raphael Simon
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: A Rare Find
description: Johan Vass tilts toward genius in his enchanting Times crossword debut.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — A rare find, indeed! We meet a new constructor today from Sweden, a restaurant worker who hasn’t yet visited the United States, although he has been solving American crossword puzzles for some time (speed-solving, I should say, with a Sunday personal best time of 10:36). This is according to Will Shortz’s print introduction, which ends in Mr. Shortz declaring, “I’m honestly in awe” (concerning this grid as well as the context of its constructor).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Ron DeSantis Is the Republican Autopsy
description: As their theory of how to move past Donald Trump, G.O.P. insiders have the governor of Florida.
content: After the Republican Party suffered a surprising (well, to Republicans) defeat in the 2012 election, the Republican National Committee famously commissioned an autopsy that tried to analyze how the party had fallen short. It made a range of recommendations, but they were distilled by the headlines — and the wishful thinking of certain party elites — into a plan for the G.O.P. to win back the presidency mostly by shifting left on immigration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: A War Is Ending. A Pennsylvania Town Exhales.
description: In Canonsburg, known for its big Fourth of July parade, many people say they are proud of America and its military but weary of the two-decade war in Afghanistan.
content: CANONSBURG, Pa. — Every year, Eric Miller brought his son Aidan to the famous Fourth of July parade in Canonsburg, an hourslong procession that draws tens of thousands of spectators, with lawn chairs set out along the route days ahead of time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Months Before Season, N.F.L. and Players Clash Over Pandemic Workouts
description: Players on 15 teams announced they would not attend off-season programming because of concerns about the coronavirus. Some may give up financial benefits in the process.
content: Five months before the regular season starts, the N.F.L. and its players are facing their first clash over playing in the pandemic, with players for nearly half of the teams vowing to skip voluntary off-season workouts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: How a Common Air Freshener Can Result in a High-Stakes Traffic Stop
description: A majority of states have laws making it illegal to hang anything from a rearview mirror that obscures a driver’s view. But critics say the laws are often used as pretexts.
content: Phil Colbert was on his way to meet his father for lunch before his shift at an Arizona auto dealership in 2019 when he saw the flashing lights of a sheriff’s patrol car in his mirror. He made sure his hands were on the steering wheel, planted at 10 and 2 as his parents had taught him, and asked why he had been stopped.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: In a Changing Boston, a New Mayor Challenges the Police
description: Three weeks into her tenure as Boston’s acting mayor, Kim Janey has done something her predecessor did not: order the police to release documents about a leader accused of sexual abuse.
content: BOSTON — Three weeks after her swearing-in as acting mayor of Boston, Kim Janey was enjoying a sort of honeymoon, enacting feel-good policies like forgiving library fines and basking in the spotlight that came with her status as the city’s first Black and first female mayor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock and The New York Times
title: Myanmar’s Protesters Face Down the Military With Slingshots and Rocks
description: What began as peaceful demonstrations against the military coup has rapidly grown into a resistance movement in which citizens use improvised weapons to fight the junta.
content: Every day, when Ko Win Kyaw goes out to demonstrate against the Myanmar military, he carries his slingshot and a supply of rocks as ammunition. It is little help against the army’s overwhelming firepower, but he says it gives him confidence and a way to strike back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Scrutiny of William and Harry’s relationship hovers over the funeral.
description: Almost 24 years ago, the world watched as a pair of brothers, ages 15 and 12, walked a mile through the grounds of Windsor Castle behind a horse-drawn carriage holding their mother’s coffin.
content: Almost 24 years ago, the world watched as a pair of brothers, ages 15 and 12, walked a mile through the grounds of Windsor Castle behind a horse-drawn carriage holding their mother’s coffin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: Realtors Want to Sell You a Home. Their Trade Group Backs Evicting Others.
description: The National Association of Realtors is advocating an end to a pandemic-era order meant to keep renters in their homes.
content: Some of the same people in charge of selling you a home have sued to make it easier to evict people from one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Something Opened With a Click
description: Leslie Rogers takes us aloft on a Saturday.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Today’s grid has one of the most disarming set of misdirects that I’ve seen in a while. As a paper solver I would have left a couple of incorrect letters in the grid and went on with my day if it weren’t for having to write this write-up, and I imagine that plenty of online solvers had to run through the alphabet a couple of times, on entries with four and five letters, no less. Leslie Rogers is fairly new; her last puzzle was the clever one on daylight saving time in March, and this is only her second themeless. I think it’s a good one — lively and original, with seven debuts tucked in throughout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan B. Garland
title: Rising Debt, Falling Income: How to Dig Out
description: More Americans over age 55 are carrying debt loads, and their nonmortgage debt grew significantly during the pandemic.
content: Angie Barajas taught special education and bilingual classes in El Paso high schools for 25 years. But after caring for two ailing family members, Ms. Barajas slid from a stable middle-class life into bankruptcy court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Ontario, hit with a virus surge, backtracks on sweeping new police powers.
description: Canada has inched ahead of the United States in new daily coronavirus cases per capita, and officials warned that worse is to come.
content: Just a day after extending and expanding its stay-at-home orders, Ontario — Canada’s most populous province — limited sweeping new powers that it had granted to the police to enforce the mandates in an effort to curb rising case numbers and hospitalizations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Crypto Is Minting Lobbyists
description: A growing web of trade groups aims to influence policies that will aid (or squash) the digital gold rush.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater, Catie Edmondson and Rachel Shorey
title: Fund-Raising Surged for Republicans Who Sought to Overturn the Election
description: The lawmakers, who encouraged their followers to protest in Washington on Jan. 6, have capitalized on the riot to draw huge campaign donations.
content: WASHINGTON — Republicans who were the most vocal in urging their followers to come to Washington on Jan. 6 to try to reverse President Donald J. Trump’s loss, pushing to overturn the election and stoking the grievances that prompted the deadly Capitol riot, have profited handsomely in its aftermath, according to new campaign data.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: A vaccine scare ripples around the world: The week in Covid-19 news.
description: Safety worries about the AstraZeneca and Johnson & Johnson Covid-19 vaccines in the United States and Europe have reverberated around the world, undercutting faith in two sorely needed shots and threatening to prolong the coronavirus pandemic in poorer countries that cannot afford to be choosy about vaccines. With new infections surging on nearly every continent, signs that the vaccination drive is in peril are emerging, most disconcertingly in the continent of Africa.
content: Safety worries about the AstraZeneca and Johnson & Johnson Covid-19 vaccines in the United States and Europe have reverberated around the world, undercutting faith in two sorely needed shots and threatening to prolong the coronavirus pandemic in poorer countries that cannot afford to be choosy about vaccines. With new infections surging on nearly every continent, signs that the vaccination drive is in peril are emerging, most disconcertingly in the continent of Africa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo, Danielle Ivory, Lauren Leatherby and Robert Gebeloff
title: Virus cases and hospitalizations rise sharply in Pennsylvania, as dozens of other states see high caseloads.
description: The U.S. vaccination campaign’s race against the spread of variants — especially B.1.1.7 — is being hobbled by rebounding U.S. tourism and entrenched vaccine hesitancy.
content: Coronavirus cases and hospitalizations are surging in Pennsylvania, as state officials warn of the impact of trends seen across the country: increased travel, relaxing restrictions and the spread of more contagious virus variants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peggy Orenstein and Ina Park
title: Fear of Contagion Won’t Depress Our Sex Lives Forever
description: As we creep back toward normal, what should we do about the rise of sexually transmitted infections?
content: Dr. Hilary Reno’s eyes widened as she scanned the waiting room at the St. Louis County Sexual Health Clinic in Missouri, where she’s the medical director. She was used to seeing a swath of humanity parked in those plastic chairs: middle-aged men secretly screening after a tryst; college students making a post-hookup pit stop; teenagers, fresh in love, testing together before taking the next step. But now, in the spring of 2019, every seat was filled, with more patients leaning up against the walls. “How,” she thought to herself, “can we possibly keep up?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: Liam Scarlett, Acclaimed British Choreographer, Dies at 35
description: He rose to fame in the dance world with remarkable speed. His subsequent downfall, amid allegations of sexual misconduct, happened just as abruptly.
content: Liam Scarlett, a British choreographer who won early acclaim both at home and internationally for his ballets, died on Friday at his home in Ipswich, England. He was 35.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: Chicago, Long Riven Over Police Conduct, Reels Anew After Shooting of 13-Year-Old
description: Chicagoans reacted with grief to the shooting of Adam Toledo, a seventh grader. Some recalled Laquan McDonald, another teen killed by the police.
content: CHICAGO — Another killing by a police officer. Another emotional mayor trying to soothe the city. Another burst of protests, vows for change, pleas for calm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis McGill Johnson
title: I’m the Head of Planned Parenthood. We’re Done Making Excuses for Our Founder.
description: We must reckon with Margaret Sanger’s association with white supremacist groups and eugenics.
content: We need to talk about Margaret Sanger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Miriam Jordan
title: Biden Wavers on Restricting Refugee Entry
description: The Biden administration will for now maintain a historically low refugee cap. But after a widespread backlash from Democrats, the White House said it would raise refugee admissions in May.
content: WASHINGTON — The White House announced on Friday that President Biden would limit the number of refugees allowed into the United States this year to the historically low level set by the Trump administration, reversing an earlier promise to welcome more than 60,000 people fleeing war and persecution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: The Moral Case for Buying Erling Haaland
description: Manchester City or another wealthy club might need to sign Erling Haaland, if only to save soccer from financial calamity.
content: As the danger bubbled to the surface, there was an audible intake of breath among Manchester City’s substitutes. Once it had passed, a few seconds later, as they exchanged glances — of admiration, of relief — came a little murmur of appreciation. In the silence of the stadium, you could hear the sounds of game recognizing game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrés R. Martínez, Mitch Smith, Alison Saldanha, Campbell Robertson and Ali Watkins
title: FedEx Gunman Bought 2 Rifles After Police Seized His Shotgun, Chief Says
description: Brandon Hole, 19, had his shotgun taken away in March 2020 after his mother raised concerns about his mental state, records show. But he was able to legally make gun purchases just months later.
content: INDIANAPOLIS — Brandon Hole, the 19-year-old man who the police say fatally shot eight people at a FedEx facility on Thursday night, legally purchased two semiautomatic rifles he used in the attack just a few months after the police seized a shotgun from him, the chief of the Indianapolis Metropolitan Police Department said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman and Ellen Almer Durston
title: Hundreds March in Chicago, Protesting Police Shooting of Adam Toledo, 13
description: The boy was fatally shot in March after a police chase in Chicago’s Little Village neighborhood.
content: CHICAGO — Hundreds of people marched through the Logan Square neighborhood in Chicago on Friday evening, calling for overhauls to the city’s police department after the fatal shooting of 13-year-old Adam Toledo by a police officer in March.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Denis Donoghue, Humanist Literary Critic, Dies at 92
description: He wrote prodigiously while teaching, first in Dublin and then in New York, and often clashed with critics he considered too political.
content: Denis Donoghue, an Irish academic whose wide-ranging literary tastes, erudite analysis of poets like T.S. Eliot and William Butler Yeats, and fierce aversion to the impositions of postmodern theory earned him a reputation as one of the last great humanist critics, died on April 6 at his home in Durham, N.C. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich, Livia Albeck-Ripka and Makiko Inoue
title: These Countries Did Well With Covid. So Why Are They Slow on Vaccines?
description: Japan, South Korea and Australia have inoculated tiny percentages of their populations. The delays risk unwinding their relative successes.
content: All through last year, as first Europe and then the United States suffered catastrophically high coronavirus infections and deaths, Pacific Rim countries staved off disaster through an array of methods. South Korea tested widely. Australia and New Zealand locked down. In Japan, people donned masks and heeded calls to isolate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: After a Year of Turmoil, Elite Universities Welcome More Diverse Freshman Classes
description: The aftermath of the George Floyd protests and a decreased reliance on standardized tests have led to more diverse admissions at elite universities.
content: Jianna Curbelo attends a career-focused public high school in New York City, works at McDonald’s and lives in the Bronx with her unemployed mother, who did not graduate from college.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Ivory, Lauren Leatherby and Robert Gebeloff
title: Least Vaccinated U.S. Counties Have Something in Common: Trump Voters
description: A Times analysis found that willingness to receive a vaccine and actual vaccination rates to date were both lower, on average, in counties that voted red in the 2020 presidential election.
content: A Times analysis found that willingness to receive a vaccine and actual vaccination rates to date were both lower, on average, in counties that voted red in the 2020 presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

title: U.S. and Japan Pledge to Advance Democratic Values
description: President Biden welcomed Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga of Japan to the White House, where they pledged to work together to counter authoritarianism and advance “shared democratic norms.”
content: President Biden welcomed Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga of Japan to the White House, where they pledged to work together to counter authoritarianism and advance “shared democratic norms.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Ou, Katie G. Nelson, Meg Felling, Shane O'Neill and Kassie Bracken
title: ‘In The Middle of Chaos’: Living With the Daunte Wright Protests at the Front Door
description: For the past several nights, Ebonie McMillan and her children watched in real time as protests over the death of Daunte Wright turned violent. Here’s what they saw.
content: For the past several nights, Ebonie McMillan and her children watched in real time as protests over the death of Daunte Wright turned violent. Here’s what they saw.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Hundreds Protest Fatal Police Shooting of 13-Year-Old in Chicago
description: Demonstrators in Chicago marched on Friday evening, calling for police reforms in response to the killing last month of Adam Toledo, one of the youngest people killed by the police in Illinois in years.
content: Demonstrators in Chicago marched on Friday evening, calling for police reforms in response to the killing last month of Adam Toledo, one of the youngest people killed by the police in Illinois in years.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 17, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, April 17, 2021.
content: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about New Yorkers whose houses were flooded with sewage in 2019 misstated the percentages of homeownership among New Yorkers of different ethnic and racial groups in 2018. The percentages given referred to homeownership within those communities, not to homeownership in the city over all. That year, 44 percent of Asian households and 43 percent of white households owned their homes, while the same was true for just 27 percent of Black households and 17 percent of Latino households.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Be Kind Whenever Possible. It Is Always Possible.’
description: We asked readers about their life philosophies. We published a selection of their responses last weekend, and now are highlighting several more.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
